page.title: All your base are belong to us

rev.comment: removing Warcraft reference; it isn't really an example of "AYB in the media"
rev.diff:
Line 32: Line 32:
*On [[2002-01-06]], an episode of the television show ''[[Futurama]]'' ("[[Anthology of Interest II]]," episode #403) featured a segment in which the robot Beserk said, "All your base are belong to us."<ref>{{cite web | author=Morton, Lewis | year=2002-01-06 | url=http://www.imsdb.com/transcripts/Futurama-Anthology-Of-Interest-II.html | title="Anthology Of Interest II" Transcript at IMSDb | work=Internet Movie Script Database | accessdate=2006-05-15}}</ref>
*On [[2002-01-06]], an episode of the television show ''[[Futurama]]'' ("[[Anthology of Interest II]]," episode #403) featured a segment in which the robot Beserk said, "All your base are belong to us."<ref>{{cite web | author=Morton, Lewis | year=2002-01-06 | url=http://www.imsdb.com/transcripts/Futurama-Anthology-Of-Interest-II.html | title="Anthology Of Interest II" Transcript at IMSDb | work=Internet Movie Script Database | accessdate=2006-05-15}}</ref>
â   â
*On [[2002]], In [[Warcraft III]], a computer game released by Blizzard Entertainment, the phrase was used as a cheat code which automatically won the game for the player in the one-player campaign mode.
 
*On [[2003-04-01]], in [[Sturgis, Michigan]], seven men aged 17 to 20 placed signs all over town that read, "All your base are belong to us. You have no chance to survive make your time." They said they were playing an [[April Fool's Day|April Fool's]] joke by mimicking the famous Flash animation that ubiquitously depicted the slogan. Not many people who saw the signs were familiar with the joke, however. Many residents were upset that the signs appeared while the U.S. was at [[2003 invasion of Iraq|war with Iraq]], and police chief Eugene Alli said the signs could be "a borderline terrorist threat depending on what someone interprets it to mean."<ref>{{cite web | author=Doyle, Holly | year=2003-04-04 | url=http://wwmt.com/engine.pl?station=wwmt&id=468&template=breakout_local.html | title="Men arrested for 'All Your Base' prank" | work=WWMT â Digital Channel 3 | accessdate=2006-05-15}}</ref>
*On [[2003-04-01]], in [[Sturgis, Michigan]], seven men aged 17 to 20 placed signs all over town that read, "All your base are belong to us. You have no chance to survive make your time." They said they were playing an [[April Fool's Day|April Fool's]] joke by mimicking the famous Flash animation that ubiquitously depicted the slogan. Not many people who saw the signs were familiar with the joke, however. Many residents were upset that the signs appeared while the U.S. was at [[2003 invasion of Iraq|war with Iraq]], and police chief Eugene Alli said the signs could be "a borderline terrorist threat depending on what someone interprets it to mean."<ref>{{cite web | author=Doyle, Holly | year=2003-04-04 | url=http://wwmt.com/engine.pl?station=wwmt&id=468&template=breakout_local.html | title="Men arrested for 'All Your Base' prank" | work=WWMT â Digital Channel 3 | accessdate=2006-05-15}}</ref>
